A Closed Book

written byGilbert Adair

2/18/2010

An isolated house deep in the Cotswolds. A writer's den, as dusty and gloomy as the cell of a medieval monk. Two people sit opposite each other, one of them talking, the other typing. But why, in such already sombre surroundings, does one of them wear thick dark glasses? And what, above all, has caused an unearthy shadow to fall across these two interwoven destinies?Apart from the several startling twists of its own brilliant plot, A Closed Book springs a few extra surprises on those readers who have already seen the film version. 'A page-turner par excellence.' Evening Standard'Gilbert Adair's spookily gripping novel blends an Agatha Christie-like twist with a Hitchcockian plot.' Marie Claire'This short, intellectually resourceful thriller...sparklingly clever, adroit and entertaining.' The Spectator'Gilbert Adair's novel has an almost cinematic, even radio-play, sense of suspense, but plays tricks only possible on the page...The finale is deliciously apt and unsettling.' Independent'Very readable indeed...a darkly entertaining soufflÃ©...A Closed Book positively invites an informed second reading.' Independent on Sunday

Love and Death on Long Island

written byGilbert Adair

Published by Open Road + Grove/Atlantic - 12/1/2007

A reserved British intellectual falls obsessively in love with a young American heartthrob, in this witty and poignant âtour de forceâ (Literary Review). When he wanders into the wrong theater and finds himself watching the wretched teen-pic Hotpants College II, cerebral British author Giles DeâAth becomes romantically obsessed with dreamboat Ronnie Bostock. Gilesâs infatuation drives him to the unthinkable: he reads American fan magazines and watches movies with titles like Tex Mex and Skid Marks. And finally, he travels to Long Island, intent on meeting Ronnie in the flesh. The basis for the hit independent film starring Jason Priestley and John Hurt, Love and Death on Long Island is a brilliant and heartrending update of Thomas Mannâs early twentieth-century novella Death in Venice. It offers both a poignant meditation on passion, and âa very funny portrait of an extraordinarily unworldly academicâs introduction to the dizzyingly incomprehensible realm of popular cultureâ (Nick Hornby). âBrief, pure, intense . . . The writing is masterly, the conjuring of contrasting worlds a triumph.â âThe Financial Times

Did you know that the movie The Dreamers is based on the book The Holy Innocents?

Paris, spring 1968. While most students take the lead in the May 'revolution', a French poet's twin son Theo and daughter Isabelle enjoy the good life in his grand Paris home. As film buffs they meet and 'adopt' modest, conservatively educated Californian student Matthew. With their parents away for a month, they drag him into an orgy of indulgence of all senses, losing all of his and the last of their innocence. A sexual threesome shakes their rapport, yet only the outside reality will break it up.
